revision.comment: /* Births */
revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1539|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1539'''. ==Events== *April – Printing of the [[Great Bible]] (''The Byble in Englyshe'') is completed and it is distributed to churches in England.<ref>{{cite book|last=Palmer|first=Alan|author2=Veronica|year=1992|title=The Chronology of British History|publisher=Century Ltd|location=London|pages=145–148|isbn=0-7126-5616-2}}</ref> Prepared by [[Myles Coverdale]], it contains much material from the [[Tyndale Bible]] (unacknowledged as this version is officially considered heretical). *''Unknown dates'' **Game Place House in [[Great Yarmouth]] becomes the first premises in England to be used regularly as a public theatre.<ref>{{cite book|first=Patrick|last=Robertson|title=The Shell Book of Firsts|location=London|publisher=Ebury Press|year=1974|isbn=0-7181-1279-2|page=189}}</ref> **[[Marie Dentière]] writes an open letter to [[Marguerite de Navarre|Marguerite of Navarre]], sister of King [[Francis I of France]]; the ''Epistre tres utile'', or "very useful letter", calls for an expulsion of Catholic clergy from France. **The first printing press in [[North America]] is set up in [[Mexico City]]. The first known book from it, ''Manual de Adultos'', appears in 1540.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Press in Colonial America|work=A Publisher’s History of American Magazines — Background and Beginnings|url=http://www.themagazinist.com/uploads/Part_4_Colonial_Printers_and_Papers.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2013-08-22}}</ref> **Teseo Ambrogio's ''Introductio in Chaldaicam lingua, Syriaca atq Armenica, & dece alias linguas'', published in [[Pavia]], introduces several [[Middle East]]ern languages to [[Western Europe]] for the first time.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Robert Estienne]] – ''Alphabetum Hebraicum'' *[[Martin Luther]] – ''[[On the Councils and the Church]]''
===Poetry=== {{Main|1539 in poetry}}
==Births== *[[February 27]] – [[Franciscus Raphelengius]], Flemish-born Dutch scholar, printer and bookseller (died [[1597 in literature|1597]])<ref>{{nl icon}} [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/_jaa002186601_01/_jaa002186601_01_0012.htm Some biographical information]</ref> *[[March 5]] – [[Christoph Pezel]], German theologian (died [[1604 in literature|1604]]) *[[April 12]] – [[Garcilaso de la Vega (chronicler)|Garcilaso de la Vega]], Spanish Peruvian ''[[mestizo]]'' chronicler (died [[1616 in literature|1616]]) *[[December 5]] – [[Fausto Paolo Sozzini]], Italian theologian (died [[1604 in literature|1604]]) *[[December 20]] – [[Paulus Melissus]], German writer in Latin, translator and composer (died [[1602 in literature|1602]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Olivier de Serres]], French writer on agriculture and horticulture (died [[1619 in literature|1619]]) **[[Jean de Tournes (1539–1615)|Jean de Tournes]], French author, printer and bookseller (died [[1615 in literature|1615]]) **[[Richard White of Basingstoke]], English jurist and historian (died [[1611 in literature|1611]])
==Deaths== *[[March 5]] – [[Kaspar Ursinus Velius]], German scholar, poet and historian (born c. 1493) *[[May 7]] – [[Ottaviano Petrucci]], Italian printer (born [[15th century in literature|1466]]) *[[July 5]] – Saint [[Anthony Maria Zaccaria]], Italian religious writer and leader of the Counter-reformation (born [[16th century in literature|1502]])<ref>[http://www.barnabites.com/stanthonyzaccaria St. Anthony Mary's biography and his writings page on the Barnabite Fathers' North American website]</ref> *[[August 10]] – [[Lanspergius]], German Carthusian monk and ascetic writer (born [[15th century in literature|1489]]) *[[November 25]] – [[Johann Alexander Brassicanus]], German author and teacher (died c. 1500) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Ferdinand Columbus]], Spanish bibliographer and cosmographer (born [[15th century in literature|1488]]) **[[Gabriel Alonso de Herrera]], Spanish author of an agricultural treatise (born [[15th century in literature|1470]])
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1539]] [[Category:1539 books]] [[Category:16th-century books| ]] [[Category:Renaissance literature]] [[Category:Early Modern literature]] [[Category:Years of the 16th century in literature]]

revision.comment: /* Sequels, spin-offs and remakes */
revision.text:
The year [[2017]] was marked, in [[science fiction]], by the following events. ==Events==
[[File:Star Wars Celebration Orlando West C Lobby Entrance 1.jpg|thumb|Fans line up at the entrance to [[Star Wars Celebration]] in Orlando to celebrate 40 years of Star Wars]]
* [[May 25]] - 40th anniversary of [[Star Wars]] was celebrated by fans worldwide. The 2017 [[Star Wars Celebration]] convention in Orlando was dedicated to this date,<ref>{{cite web|title=40 Year Anniversary of ‘Star Wars’ Celebrated At 4-Day Fan Event|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2017/04/13/40-year-anniversary-of-star-wars-celebrated-at-4-day-fan-event/|website=CBS San Francisco}}</ref> and several anniversary collectibles were released.<ref>{{cite web|title=DISNEY STORE CELEBRATES THE 40TH ANNIVERSARY OF STAR WARS|url=http://www.starwars.com/news/disney-store-celebrates-the-40th-anniversary-of-star-wars|website=starwars.com}}</ref> * [[December 14]] - [[Proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney|Disney announced it would acquire 21st Century Fox]] for $52.4 billion. The deal includes rights for many science fiction franchises, such as [[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]], [[Alien (franchise)|Alien]], [[Futurama]], [[Firefly (franchise)|Firefly]], among others.
===Deaths=== * [[January 25]] - [[John Hurt]], English actor ([[Alien (film)|Alien]], [[Contact (1997 American film)|Contact]], [[Snowpiercer]], [[Nineteen Eighty-Four (1984 film)|Nineteen Eighty-Four]], [[V for Vendetta (film)|V for Vendetta]]) * [[February 7]] - [[Richard Hatch (actor)|Richard Hatch]], American actor ([[Battlestar Galactica]]) * [[February 25]] - [[Bill Paxton]], American actor ([[The Terminator]], [[Weird Science (film)|Weird Science]], [[Aliens (film)|Aliens]], [[Predator 2]], [[Edge of Tomorrow]]) * [[June 9]] - [[Adam West]], American actor ([[Batman (TV series)|Batman]], [[Robinson Crusoe on Mars]]) * [[July 15]] - [[Martin Landau]], American actor ([[Space: 1999]]) * [[August 19]] - [[Brian Aldiss]], English writer ([[Super-Toys Last All Summer Long]]) * [[August 31]] - [[Richard Anderson]], American actor ([[The Six Million Dollar Man]], [[The Bionic Woman]], [[Forbidden Planet]]) * [[September 10]] - [[Len Wein]], American comic book writer ([[Swamp Thing]], [[Wolverine (character)|Wolverine]]) * [[September 15]] - [[Harry Dean Stanton]], American actor ([[Alien (film)|Alien]], [[Escape from New York]], [[Repo Man (film)|Repo Man]], [[The Avengers (2012 film)|The Avengers]]) * [[November 25]] - [[Rance Howard]], American actor ([[Independence Day (1996 film)|Independence Day]], [[Cocoon (film)|Cocoon]], [[Mars Attacks!]])
==Literary releases== *''[[The Collapsing Empire]]'' by [[John Scalzi]] *''[[The Delirium Brief]]'' by [[Charles Stross]] *''[[Empire Games (novel)|Empire Games]]'' by [[Charles Stross]] *''[[Forgotten Worlds (novel)|Forgotten Worlds]]'', The Silence #2 by [[D. Nolan Clark]] *''[[Martians Abroad]]'' by [[Carrie Vaughn]] *''[[New York 2140 (novel)|New York 2140]]'' by [[Kim Stanley Robinson]] *''[[Persepolis Rising]]'' by [[James S.A. Corey]] *''[[Seek and Destroy (novel)|Seek and Destroy]]'', America Rising #2 by [[William C. Dietz]] *''[[The Stone Sky]]'', The Broken Earth #3 by [[N. K. Jemisin]] *''[[Vanguard: The Genesis Fleet]]'' by [[John G. Hemry|Jack Campbell]] *''[[Children of the Fleet]]'' by [[Orson Scott Card]] <!--http://www.cam-info.net/forthcomingsf.html-->
==Films== ===Original=== * ''[[Attraction (film)|Attraction]]'', by [[Fyodor Bondarchuk]] * ''[[Battle of Memories]]'', by [[Leste Chen]] * ''[[Dance to Death]]'', by Andrei Volgin * ''[[Life (2017 film)|Life]]'', by [[Daniel Espinosa]] * ''[[Orbita 9]]'' by Hatem Khraiche * ''[[OtherLife]]'', by [[Ben C. Lucas]] * ''[[Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets]]'', by [[Luc Besson]]
===Sequels, spin-offs and remakes=== * ''[[Alien Covenant]]'', by [[Ridley Scott]] * ''[[Blade Runner 2049]]'', by [[Denis Villeneuve]] * ''[[Ghost in the Shell (2017 film)|Ghost in the Shell]]'', by [[Rupert Sanders]] * ''[[Star Wars: The Last Jedi]]'', by [[Rian Johnson]] * ''[[War for the Planet of the Apes]]'', by [[Matt Reeves]]
==Television== *''[[Dimension 404]]'' *''[[The Expanse (TV series)|The Expanse]]'' (season 2) *''[[Extinct (2017 TV series)|Extinct]] * ''[[The Orville]]'' *''[[Philip K. Dick's Electric Dreams]]'' *''[[Star Trek: Discovery]]'' *''[[Time After Time (TV series)|Time After Time]]'' *''[[Timeless (TV series)|Timeless]]'' <!--[[Ultraman Zero: The Chronicle]]-->
==Video games<ref>[http://gameranx.com/features/id/84325/article/top-upcoming-sci-fi-video-games-of-2017/ Top Upcoming Sci-Fi Video Games of 2017]</ref>== *[[Destiny 2]] *[[Endless Space 2]] *[[Horizon Zero Dawn]] *[[Mass Effect: Andromeda]] *[[Nier Automata]] *[[Prey (2017 video game)|Prey]] *[[Star Wars Battlefront II (2017 video game)|Star Wars: Battlefront II]]
== Awards == ===Hugo Award=== [[File:Hawk Ostby at the Hugo Awards Ceremony, Worldcon, Helsinki.jpg|thumb|Producer of The Expanse [[Hawk Ostby]] accepting his [[Hugo Award]]]]
*Best dramatic presentation (long form) - [[Arrival (film)|Arrival]] *Best dramatic presentation (short form) - [[The Expanse (TV series)|The Expanse]]
===Locus Award=== [[Locus Award for Best Science Fiction Novel|Best Science Fiction Novel]] - ''[[Death's End]]'' by [[Liu Cixin]] === Saturn Award === {{main|43rd Saturn Awards}}
*Best science fiction film: [[Rogue One: A Star Wars Story]]
*Best Science Fiction Television Series: [[Westworld (TV series)|Westworld]] ===Academy Award=== * ''[[Arrival (film)|Arrival]]'' for Best Sound Editing. ===Nobel Award for literature=== *[[Kazuo Ishiguro]], author of 2005 science fiction novel [[Never Let Me Go (novel)|Never Let Me Go]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title = [[:Category:Science fiction by year|Science fiction by year]] | years = [[2017]] | before = [[2016 in science fiction|2016]] | after = [[2018 in science fiction|2018]] }} {{S-end}}

revision.comment: removed part about Ralph Vaughan Williams. Bliss never studied composition with Vaughan Williams, and certainly didn't write A Colour Symphony under his supervision.
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''A Colour Symphony''''', Op. 24, F. 106, was written by [[Arthur Bliss]] in 1921–22.<ref name=Harvard>{{cite book|last=Randel|first=Don Michael|title=The Harvard dictionary of music|year=2003|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-01163-2|page=191}}</ref> It was his first major work for [[orchestra]]<ref name=class/> and remains one of his best known compositions.
== Orchestration == The symphony is scored for 3 flutes (one doubling on piccolo), 2 oboes, cor anglais, 2 clarinets, bass clarinet, 2 bassoons, double bassoon, 4 horns, 3 trumpets, 3 trombones, tuba, 2 tympanists, cymbals, 2 harps and strings.
==History==
''A Colour Symphony'' was written to be performed at the [[Three Choirs Festival]], held in 1922 in [[Gloucester]],<ref>{{cite book|title=The concise Oxford dictionary of music|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press US|isbn=978-0-19-860884-4|author=Bourne, Joyce|author2=Michael Kennedy|page=153}}</ref> at the invitation of Sir [[Edward Elgar]], who also invited [[Herbert Howells]] and [[Eugene Aynsley Goossens|Eugene Goossens]] to write a piece each.<ref>[http://www.naxos.com/mainsite/blurbs_reviews.asp?item_code=9.80004&catNum=9.80004&filetype=About%20this%20Recording&language=English Bliss: Colour Symphony]</ref> Howells wrote ''Sine Nomine'' for wordless chorus,<ref name=mwi>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicweb-international.com/classRev/2003/Apr03/british_choral_music.htm|last=Culot|first=Hubert|title=Review: British Choral Music|publisher=MusicWeb International|year=2003}}</ref> which was not given its second performance until his centenary year 70 years later, in 1992.<ref>[http://www.simonlindley.org.uk/howells.html Romanticism in Retrospect]</ref> Goossens wrote a piece called ''Silence'' for chorus and orchestra.<ref name=mwi/> Elgar's own contribution was his orchestration of [[Johann Sebastian Bach]]'s ''Fantasia and Fugue in C minor''.
Bliss decided to write a symphony, but was at first undecided what the theme or character of the work would be. He could not get started for some weeks. One day, by chance, he came across a book on [[heraldry]] in which he read of the symbolic meanings attached to certain colours; this gave him the notion of writing a work about colours. He attempted to give each movement a character corresponding to these meanings, but without attempting to depict the colours themselves.<ref>[http://www.emusic.com/lists/showlist.html?lid=16782048 The eMusic Dozen: British Composers]</ref> Bliss dedicated the symphony to the conductor [[Adrian Boult]].<ref name=class/>
The first performance, with the [[London Symphony Orchestra]], in [[Gloucester Cathedral]] on 7 September 1922, was conducted by the composer. It was not well received at first, due to poor preparation. The work uses a large orchestra, but the platform was so taken up with the chorus required for other works also being performed, that several instruments had to be omitted.<ref name=greene>[https://books.google.com/books?id=m3S7PIxe0mwC&pg=PA1199&lpg=PA1199&dq=bliss+colour+symphony+gloucester&source=bl&ots=KT7QuTP2Va&sig=7HENnXAqSA-G0UcegzQHMFAQ0Oc&hl=en&ei=VZ3RSb_iL6Xg6gPx_6yaBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result Greene's Biographical Encyclopedia of Composers]</ref> Elgar attended, but found it "disconcertingly modern".<ref name=class>[http://www.classicalarchives.com/work/92969.html#about Classical Archives]</ref> It nevertheless entered the repertoire and has been recorded various times, although it is now an infrequent visitor to concert platforms.
==Analysis==
The four movements are:
{| Class="wikitable" | style="background:purple"|{{fontcolor|white|'''Purple'''}} | rowspan="2"|{{nowrap|'''''Andante maestoso'''''}} | rowspan="2"|slow and majestic in pace and ceremonial in character |- | The colour of [[Amethyst]]s, [[Medieval pageant|Pageantry]], [[Royal family|Royalty]] and [[Death]]''' |- | style="background:red"|{{fontcolor|white|'''Red'''}} | rowspan="2"| '''''Allegro vivace''''' | rowspan="2"|a glittering, spiky and percussive scherzo, reminiscent of [[Igor Stravinsky|Stravinsky]].<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/a-colour-symphony-for-orchestra-op-24-f-106 Answers.com: A Colour Symphony]</ref> |- | The colour of [[Ruby|Rubies]], [[Wine]], [[Saturnalia|Revelry]], [[Furnace]]s, [[Courage]] and [[Magic (paranormal)|Magic]]''' |- | style="background:blue"|{{fontcolor|white|'''Blue'''}} | rowspan="2"|'''''Gently flowing''''' | rowspan="2"|slow, with chords used to depict the lapping of water against a moored boat or a pier |- | The colour of [[Sapphire]]s, Deep [[Water]], [[Sky|Skies]], [[Loyalty]] and [[Melancholia|Melancholy]]''' |- | style="background:green"|{{fontcolor|white|'''Green'''}} | rowspan="2"|'''''Moderato''''' | rowspan="2"|a double [[fugue]] (which has been described as "[[Arnold Schoenberg|Schoenbergian]]"<ref>{{cite web|last=Barnett|first=Rob|url=http://www.musicweb-international.com/classrev/2007/Jan07/Bliss_5865892.htm|title=Review: Bliss - Orchestral Works (EMI)|publisher=MusicWeb International|year=2007}}</ref>) on violas, strings, clarinets and woodwinds, leading to a triumphant climax |- | The colour of [[Emerald]]s, [[Hope]], [[Youth]], [[Joy]], [[Spring (season)|Spring]] and [[Victory]]''' |- |}
A theme from towards the end of the ''Red'' movement was used as the signature tune of the televised "[[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Serotsky|first=Paul|url=http://www.musicweb-international.com/Programme_Notes/bliss_colour.htm|title=Programme Notes: Bliss - A Colour Symphony|publisher=MusicWeb International|year=2017}}</ref>
==Revision==
In 1932, Bliss revised the [[coda (music)|coda]]s of the first two movements.<ref name=Harvard/> He conducted the revised work himself in a recording with the [[London Symphony Orchestra]] in 1955.<ref>[http://newsgroups.derkeiler.com/Archive/Rec/rec.music.classical.recordings/2005-09/msg05493.html derkeiler.com]</ref> Bliss made a stereo recording with the [[BBC Welsh Symphony Orchestra]].
The last movement, "Green", was separately published as ''Pyonepsion''.
==Other uses== In 1977, a [[ballet]] called ''Royal Offering'' was created, with music based on ''A Colour Symphony''.
A short extract from the 'Red' movement was used as the opening music to [[BBC]] TV coverage of [[The Proms]] until 2011.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/proms/2010/about/questions.shtml BBC Proms 2010] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402173527/http://www.bbc.co.uk/proms/2010/about/questions.shtml |date=April 2, 2011 }}</ref>
The British artist Kevin Laycock created a visual piece called ''Four Movements in Colour'', in which he attempted to portray, in colour, the sounds created by Arthur Bliss.<ref>[http://www.drumcroon.org.uk/Arch1/klaycock/LaycockTeacherNotes.doc Four Movements in Colour: Recent Paintings by Kevin Laycock] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060930050504/http://www.drumcroon.org.uk/Arch1/klaycock/LaycockTeacherNotes.doc |date=September 30, 2006 }}</ref> In 2004, Laycock created a series of paintings called ''Tectonics'' as a direct response to Bliss's ''A Colour Symphony'' using parallel compositional structures.<ref>[http://www.colour-journal.org/2007/1/10/07110gallery.pdf Uncertain Harmonies]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== * [[Arthur Bliss]], liner notes to the recording by [[Anthony Collins (composer)|Anthony Collins]] and the [[London Symphony Orchestra]]
==External links== *[http://unsungsymphonies.blogspot.com/2011/02/bliss-colour-symphony.html Article on Color Symphony] (Accessed 17 May 2011)
{{Arthur Bliss}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Colour Symphony, A}} [[Category:20th-century symphonies|Bliss]] [[Category:Compositions by Arthur Bliss]] [[Category:1922 compositions]] [[Category:Color]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{pp-move-indef}} {{Infobox Simpsons episode |episode_name=A Streetcar Named Marge |episode_no=61 |prod_code=8F18{{sfn|Richmond & Coffman|1997|p=93}} |airdate=October 1, 1992{{cite web |url=http://www.thesimpsons.com/#/recaps/season-4_episode-2 |title=A Streetcar Named Marge |accessdate=2011-09-17 |publisher=The Simpsons.com}} |show runner=[[Al Jean]] & [[Mike Reiss]] |writer=[[Jeff Martin (writer)|Jeff Martin]] |director=[[Rich Moore]] |blackboard="My name is not "Dr. Death""{{sfn|Richmond & Coffman|1997|p=93}} |couch_gag=The couch turns into a tentacled brown monster.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/simpsons/episodeguide/season4/page3.shtml |title=A Streetcar Named Marge |accessdate=2007-08-24 |author1=Martyn, Warren |author2=Wood, Adrian |year=2000 |publisher=BBC}} |focus=[[Marge Simpson|Marge]] |guest_star=[[Jon Lovitz]] as Llewellyn Sinclair and Ms. Sinclair
[[Phil Hartman]] as [[Lionel Hutz]] and [[Troy McClure]] |image= |image_caption= |commentary=[[Matt Groening]]
[[Al Jean]]
[[Mike Reiss]]
[[Jeff Martin (writer)|Jeff Martin]]
[[Hank Azaria]]
[[Jon Lovitz]] |season=4 }} "'''A Streetcar Named Marge'''" is the second episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]''' [[The Simpsons (season 4)|fourth season]]. It first aired on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox network]] in the United States on October 1, 1992. In the episode, [[Marge Simpson|Marge]] wins the role of [[Blanche DuBois]] in a [[community theatre]] [[musical theatre|musical]] version of [[Tennessee Williams]]' ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire]]''. [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] offers little support for his wife's acting pursuits, and Marge begins to see parallels between him and [[Stanley Kowalski]], the play's boorish lead male character. The episode contains a [[subplot]] in which [[Maggie Simpson]] attempts to retrieve her [[pacifier]] from a strict [[day care|daycare]] owner. [[Jeff Martin (writer)|Jeff Martin]] wrote the episode, and [[Rich Moore]] served as director. [[Jon Lovitz]] made his fourth guest appearance on ''The Simpsons'', this time as musical director [[Llewellyn Sinclair]], as well as Llewellyn's sister, who runs the daycare. The episode generated controversy for its original song about [[New Orleans]], which contains several unflattering lyrics about the city. One New Orleans newspaper published the lyrics before the episode aired, prompting numerous complaints to the local Fox affiliate; in response, the president of Fox Broadcasting issued an apology to anyone who was offended. Despite the controversial song, the episode was well received by many fans, and show creator [[Matt Groening]] has named it one of his favorite episodes. ==Plot== While [[Homer Simpson|Homer]], [[Bart Simpson|Bart]] and [[Lisa Simpson|Lisa]] are watching television, [[Marge Simpson|Marge]] announces that she is going to audition for a local musical production of ''A Streetcar Named Desire'', and she wants to meet new people because she usually spends all day caring for [[Maggie Simpson|Maggie]]. The rest of the family pay no attention and continue to watch television. The musical, ''Oh, Streetcar!'', is directed by Llewellyn Sinclair. After [[Ned Flanders|Ned]] is cast as Stanley Kowalski, Marge auditions for Blanche DuBois. Llewellyn immediately rejects Marge, explaining that Blanche is supposed to be a "delicate flower being trampled by an uncouth lout". However, as a dejected Marge calls home and takes Homer's dinner order, Llewellyn realizes that she is perfect for the role. The next day, Maggie causes distractions when Marge brings her to rehearsal, so Llewellyn tells Marge to enroll the baby at the daycare center, The [[Ayn Rand]] School for Tots, which is run by his sister Ms. Sinclair, who immediately confiscates Maggie's pacifier. Maggie and the other babies later engage in an attempt to retrieve their pacifiers, but Ms. Sinclair thwarts their efforts and sends Maggie to a [[playpen]]. During rehearsal, Marge struggles with a scene in which Blanche is supposed to break a glass bottle and attack Stanley, but she cannot muster enough anger towards Stanley to break the bottle. After coming home, Marge asks Homer to help her learn her lines, but Homer is uninterested. The day before the performance, Marge and Ned are again practising the bottle scene as Homer arrives to drive Marge home. Homer repeatedly interrupts the rehearsal. Imagining that Stanley is Homer, Marge finally smashes the bottle and lunges at Ned. The next day at the daycare center, Maggie again attempts to regain her pacifier. With assistance from her fellow babies, following a complicated plan, she succeeds and wildly distributes pacifiers to all the small children. Homer retrieves her, and he and his children go to attend the musical. Homer immediately falls into boredom, but he perks up when Marge appears on stage. While Homer slowly learns the show's plot, he appears sad. At the end of the musical, Marge receives a warm reaction from the crowd, but she misinterprets Homer's sadness for boredom. She confronts him with frustration and hostility, but Homer is able to explain that he was genuinely moved by the play. He feels for Blanche's situation, and he realizes Marge's feelings along with it. He expresses his intentions to be the husband that she deserves—someone to have in her life who loves her—not like Stanley who neglects and mistreats his wife. Marge realizes that Homer really did watch the musical, and the two happily leave the theater.{{sfn|Richmond & Coffman|1997|p=93}} ==Production== ===Writing and music=== [[File:Jameslbrooks.jpg|thumb|upright|Producer [[James L. Brooks]] pitched the idea of Marge playing Blanche DuBois.]] "A Streetcar Named Marge" was conceived about two years before it aired on television.Martin, Jeff. (2004). Commentary for "A Streetcar Named Marge", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. Jeff Martin first pitched the idea of Homer being in a theatrical production of ''[[1776 (play)|1776]]''; producer [[James L. Brooks]] then suggested that Marge could play Blanche DuBois in ''A Streetcar Named Desire''. Brooks saw that Marge's relationship with Homer was similar to Blanche's relationship with Stanley, and he wanted to use that fact to build the emotional arc for an episode. The estate of [[Tennessee Williams]] would not let the show use large excerpts from the actual play, since the work was copyrighted. However, Fox lawyer Anatole Klebanow said that original songs based on the play were acceptable. According to producer [[Mike Reiss]], Klebanow even promised to "take [their] case to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] to get [the] episode aired."Reiss, Mike. (2004). Commentary for "A Streetcar Named Marge", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. Martin later explained that while the songs made the episode funnier, they also made it harder to write. The Maggie subplot was present in Martin's episode pitch.Jean, Al. (2004). Commentary for "A Streetcar Named Marge", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. The music in the sequence is [[Elmer Bernstein]]'s [[march (music)|march]] theme from ''[[The Great Escape (film)|The Great Escape]]''. ''Simpsons'' composer [[Alf Clausen]] secured the rights to the score, along with the original orchestra charts. ''The Great Escape'' had been Martin's favorite film as a child, and he said "it was so exciting and so stirring" to hear the music being performed by the ''Simpsons''' studio orchestra. ===Animation=== "A Streetcar Named Marge" posed a challenge to the show's [[animation director]]s. The episode contains many long [[set piece]]s, especially during the third and final act, which includes the end of the Maggie subplot and the performance of the musical. Several scenes required the animators to draw dozens of background characters. [[Rich Moore]], the head director, initially feared the episode would not be completed in time. [[David Silverman (animator)|David Silverman]], the supervising director, also had doubts; according to Martin, Moore sent back a cartoon of himself reading the script with his eyes popping out and his jaw dropped. Producer [[Al Jean]] said that Moore "worked himself to death" to produce the episode's most elaborate sequences. A number of scenes that appeared in the [[storyboard]] and [[animatic]] were reordered or dropped altogether in the final version of the episode. Much of the Maggie subplot, for example, was modified before the episode aired. A scene in which the babies lock Ms. Sinclair in her office is missing from the final version of the episode.Moore, Rich. (2004). Commentary for "A Streetcar Named Marge", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. ===Voice acting=== All the main ''Simpsons'' [[List of The Simpsons cast members#Regular cast|cast members]] lent their voices to the episode, along with semi-regulars [[Maggie Roswell]] and [[Phil Hartman]]. Assistant producer [[Lona Williams]] also had a minor speaking role. Comedian [[Jon Lovitz]], who played Llewellyn Sinclair and Ms. Sinclair, made his fourth guest appearance on ''The Simpsons''; he had previously voiced characters in "[[The Way We Was]]", "[[Brush with Greatness]]", and "[[Homer Defined]]". Lovitz later worked with Al Jean and Mike Reiss in the animated sitcom ''[[The Critic]]'', and returned to ''The Simpsons'' for the episodes "[[A Star Is Burns]]", "[[Hurricane Neddy]]", "[[Half-Decent Proposal]]", "[[The Ziff Who Came to Dinner]]" and "[[Homerazzi]]". In 2006, Lovitz was named the eighth-best ''Simpsons'' guest star by [[IGN]].{{cite web |url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/730/730566p4.html |title=Top 25 Simpsons Guest Appearances |accessdate=2007-03-25 |last1=Goldman |first1= Eric |last2=Iverson |first2= Dan |last3=Zoromski |first3= Brian |date= January 4, 2010|publisher= IGN |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070306095518/http://tv.ign.com/articles/730/730566p4.html |archivedate=6 March 2007 |deadurl=no}} ==Cultural references== [[File:Simpsons Hitchcock.png|left|200px|thumb|Alfred Hitchcock walking his dogs, a reference to his [[List of Alfred Hitchcock cameo appearances|cameo]] in ''[[The Birds (film)|The Birds]]'']] Though ''Oh, Streetcar!'' is based on ''A Streetcar Named Desire'', the title of the musical alludes to the theatrical [[revue]] ''[[Oh! Calcutta!]]''. Besides Blanche and Stanley, characters from ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' who appear in ''Oh, Streetcar!'' include Stella (played by [[Helen Lovejoy]]), the Young Collector (played by [[Apu Nahasapeemapetilon]]), Mitch (played by [[Lionel Hutz]]), the Doctor (played by [[Chief Wiggum]]), Steve (played by [[Jasper Beardley]], although Apu originally said he was playing Steve), and Pablo (originally played by [[Otto Mann]] but taken over by Llewellyn prior to curtain). The musical's closing song, "Kindness of Strangers", is a reference to Blanche's last line in the original play: "I have always depended on the kindness of strangers." However, the song is very cheery in tone, intentionally missing the point of Blanche's line, which is meant by the playwright Tennessee Williams to be ironic. The episode contains multiple references to [[Ayn Rand]]'s novels and [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivist philosophy]]. Maggie's daycare center is called the "Ayn Rand School for Tots", and Ms. Sinclair can be seen reading a book called ''The Fountainhead Diet'', a reference to Rand's novel ''[[The Fountainhead]]''. On the wall of the daycare is a poster that reads "Helping is Futile", an allusion to Rand's rejection of the ethical doctrine of [[altruism (ethics)|altruism]]. Another wall sign reads "A is A", the [[law of identity]], which plays a central role in Rand's novel ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]''.{{sfn|Turner|2004|pp=64–65}} The Ayn Rand School for Tots is seen again in the 2012 [[short film]] "[[The Longest Daycare]]".{{cite news |last=Snierson |first=Dan |title='The Simpsons': Exclusive details on the next big-screen adventure (it's short, silent, and in 3-D)! |url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/05/22/the-simpsons-short-film/ |accessdate= 2012-07-05 |work= [[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=2012-05-22}} The Maggie subplot uses the musical score of ''[[The Great Escape (film)|The Great Escape]]'' and contains several other allusions to the film. At one point, Ms. Sinclair punishes Maggie by sending her to a playpen called "the box", a play on the solitary confinement facility called "the cooler" from the 1963 film. Maggie even bounces a ball against the wall of the playpen, as [[Steve McQueen]]'s character Virgil Hilts does throughout the film while he is in confinement. In the scene when Homer, Bart and Lisa pick up Maggie from the daycare center, babies are perched all over the building, staring at the family and quietly sucking on pacifiers. This is a spoof of the final shot of [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s ''[[The Birds (film)|The Birds]]''. Indeed, a cartoon-version of Hitchcock can be seen walking his dogs past the daycare, a reference to his own [[List of Hitchcock cameo appearances|cameo appearance]] in the film. The episode also contains an allusion to the opera scene in ''[[Citizen Kane]]'', in which Homer plays with a shredded playbill while he watches his wife in the musical. ==Merchandise== All the songs from "A Streetcar Named Marge" were released on [[Rhino Entertainment|Rhino Records]]' 2000 album ''[[Songs in the Key of Springfield]]''.{{cite news |title=Songs in the Key of Springfield |date=1997-03-27 |page=F4 |work=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |author =Kloer, Phil}} The episode was included in the 2005 [[VHS]] set ''The Simpsons Go Hollywood''{{cite news |title=Home Video |date=2000-01-14 |page=51 |work=[[The Star-Ledger]]}}{{cite news |title=Another Homer for the Simpsons |date=2000-01-14 |page=11J |work=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |author =Maurstad, Tom}} and released on [[DVD]] in 2004 as part of [[The Simpsons (season 4)#DVD release|''The Simpsons Complete Fourth Season'']]. Jon Lovitz participated in the DVD's [[audio commentary]], alongside Matt Groening, Al Jean, Mike Reiss, Jeff Martin, and [[Hank Azaria]].''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season''. 1992–1993. DVD. 20th Century Fox, 2004. ==Reception== [[File:Matt_Groening_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg|thumb|upright|''The Simpsons'' creator [[Matt Groening]] includes the episode among his favorites.]] In its original broadcast, "A Streetcar Named Marge" finished 32nd in ratings for the week of September 27 – October 4, 1992, with a [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen rating]] of 11.8, equivalent to approximately 11.0 million viewing households. It was the second highest-rated show on the Fox network that week, following ''[[Married... with Children]]''.{{cite news |title=New romantic comedies give CBS boost |work=Sun-Sentinel |author =Hastings, Deborah |page=6E |date=October 9, 1992 }} Since airing, it has received many positive reviews from fans and television critics. Michael Moran of ''[[The Times]]'' ranked the episode as the seventh best in the show's history.{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article6988097.ece?token=null&offset=0&page=1 |title=The 10 best Simpsons episodes ever |last=Moran |first=Michael |date=January 14, 2010 |work=[[The Times]] |accessdate=2010-01-14 |location=London}} ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'''s Dalton Ross lauded it as "the show's best ever musical episode",{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,649847,00.html |title=The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season |accessdate=2007-09-06 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |author=Ross, Dalton |date=2004-06-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016163549/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C649847%2C00.html |archivedate=16 October 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }} while [[Dave Kehr]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' called it a "brilliant ... parody of Broadway musicals that should be required viewing for every [[Tony Award|Tony]] viewer."{{cite news |first=Dave |last=Kehr |title='The Simpsons':The Complete Fourth Season. |work=[[The New York Times]] |page=E7 |date=2004-06-15}} In a list of his favorite episodes, Kevin Williamson of [[Canadian Online Explorer]] added, "As pitch-perfect eviscerations of community theatre go, this tops ''[[Waiting for Guffman]]''."{{cite web |url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Television/TV_Shows/S/Simpsons/2003/02/16/735323.html |title='The Simpsons' hits a Homer run |accessdate=2007-09-06 |date=2004-06-18 |publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]] |author=Williamson, Kevin |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130101082231/http://jam.canoe.ca/Television/TV_Shows/S/Simpsons/2003/02/16/735323.html |archivedate=2013-01-01 |df= }} Series creator [[Matt Groening]] has listed it as one of his own favorites, calling the subplot "Maggie's finest moment",{{cite news |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,275114,00.html |title=Springfield of Dreams |accessdate=2007-08-26 |date=2000-01-14 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |author =Snierson, Dan}} and future ''Simpsons'' guest star [[Trey Anastasio]] said the episode "may have been the best TV show ever".{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,237327,00.html |title=S.A.T.'S For Rockers |accessdate=2007-09-06 |date=2000-05-17 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |first=Wook |last=Kim |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016163540/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C237327%2C00.html |archivedate=16 October 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }} Executive producer [[James L. Brooks]] also listed it as one of his favorites, saying it "showed we could go into areas no one thought we could go into".{{cite news |title=Insiders name their favorite episodes |date=2007-05-20 |page=10F |work=[[Star Tribune]] |author =Justin, Neil}} Following the episode, the [[Ayn Rand Society]] called Groening to say they were amazed at the references to Rand. They also asked him if the show was making fun of them.Groening, Matt. (2004). Commentary for "A Streetcar Named Marge", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. In 1993, "A Streetcar Named Marge" and "[[Mr. Plow]]" were submitted for the [[Primetime Emmy Award]] for "[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series|Outstanding Comedy Series]]". Before this season, the series had only been allowed to compete in the "[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program (For Programming less than One Hour)|Outstanding Animated Program]]" category, winning twice, but in early 1993 the rules were changed so that animated television shows would be able to submit nominations for "Outstanding Comedy Series".{{cite news |title=`Simpsons' get Emmy 's respect — Academy lets series drop cartoon status to compete as sitcom |date=1993-02-02 |page=B4 |work=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |author =Holloway, Diane}} However, the Emmy voters were hesitant to pit cartoons against live action programs, and ''The Simpsons'' did not receive a nomination. The ''Simpsons''' crew submitted episodes for Outstanding Comedy Series the next season, but again these were not nominated.{{cite video |people=Jean, Al |year=2004 |title=The Simpsons season 4 DVD commentary for the episode "[[Mr. Plow]]" |medium=DVD |publisher=20th Century Fox}} Since then, the show has submitted episodes in the animation category and has won seven times.[http://www.emmys.org/awards/awardsearch.php Emmy Awards official site] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014192522/http://www.emmys.org/awards/awardsearch.php |date=October 14, 2008 }} "The Simpsons" ''emmys.org''. Retrieved on 2007-09-08. ===Controversy=== [[File:Jeff Martin.jpg|alt=Martin smiling|thumb|Writer Jeff Martin (pictured here in 1994) received criticism for satirizing New Orleans]] The musical within the episode contains a controversial song about New Orleans, which describes the city as a "home of pirates, drunks and whores", among other things. Jeff Martin, the writer of the episode, had meant the song to be a parody of a song in ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street|Sweeney Todd]]'', which speaks of London in unflattering terms ("There's No Place Like London").Martin, Jeff (2004). "The Cajun Controversy", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. Al Jean later explained that two [[Cajun]] characters were supposed to walk out of the theater in disgust, but none of the voice actors could provide a convincing Cajun accent.{{cite news |title='Simpsons' takes a shot at Crescent City |date=1992-10-01 |page=A1 |work=[[The Times-Picayune]] |author =Lorando, Mark}} An early version of the scene can be seen in an animatic included in the DVD boxset.Moore, Rich. (2004). Animatic for the episode "A Streetcar Named Marge", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. Before the premiere of the fourth season, the producers sent two episodes to critics: "[[Kamp Krusty]]" and "A Streetcar Named Marge". A New Orleans critic viewed "A Streetcar Named Marge" and published the song lyrics in his newspaper before the episode aired. Many readers took the lyrics out of context, and New Orleans' then-Fox affiliate, [[WNOL-TV]] (then-owned by musician [[Quincy Jones]]; the Fox affiliation for the area later moved to [[WVUE-DT|WVUE]]), received about one hundred complaints on the day the episode aired. Several local radio stations also held on-air protests in response to the song.{{cite news |title=Fox apologizes for 'Simpsons' |date=1992-10-02 |page=B1 |work=[[The Times-Picayune]] |author =Lorando, Mark}} At the urging of WNOL, Fox president [[Jamie Kellner]] released a statement on October 1, 1992: {{cquote|It has come to our attention that a comedic song about New Orleans in tonight's episode of "The Simpsons" has offended some city residents and officials. Viewers who watch the episode will realize that the song is in fact a parody of the opening numbers of countless Broadway musicals, which are designed to set the stage for the story that follows. That is the only purpose of this song. We regret that the song, taken out of context, has caused offense. This was certainly not the intention of "The Simpsons" production staff or Fox Broadcasting Company."The Cajun Controversy" (2004), in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Fourth Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox.}} The ''Simpsons''' producers rushed out a [[chalkboard gag]] for "[[Homer the Heretic]]", which aired a week after "A Streetcar Named Marge". It read, "I will not defame New Orleans." The gag was their attempt to apologize for the song and hopefully bring the controversy to an end. "We didn't realize people would get so mad", said Al Jean. "It was the best apology we could come up with in eight words or less."{{cite news |title=Bart chalks up apology for New Orleans song |date=1992-10-08 |page=A1 |work=[[The Times-Picayune]] |author =Lorando, Mark}} The issue passed quickly, and a person in a Bart Simpson costume even served as [[Krewe of Tucks]] Grand Marshal at the 1993 [[New Orleans Mardi Gras]].{{cite news |title=For Silver Celebration, Tucks 'Lov-A-Da Music |date=1993-02-21 |page=D7 |work=[[The Times-Picayune]]}} The episode generated further controversy in September 2005, when [[Channel 4]] in the United Kingdom decided to air the episode a week after [[Hurricane Katrina]] struck New Orleans. Arguing that the episode was an insensitive choice, given recent events, several viewers filed complaints with [[Ofcom]]. Two days later, Channel 4 apologized on-air and directly contacted all those who had complained. Channel 4 had screened the episode for offensive content, but the reviews focused on the main content of the episode, and the song was not considered a key part of the plot. Channel 4 promised to update their review process to ensure that similar incidents would not occur.{{cite web|url=http://www.ofcom.org.uk/tv/obb/prog_cb/pcb49/#skip |title=Issue number 46 |accessdate=2007-08-24 |year=2005 |publisher=Ofcom |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070813150912/http://www.ofcom.org.uk/tv/obb/prog_cb/pcb49/ |archivedate=13 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist |colwidth=30em}} ===Bibliography=== *{{cite book |last=Groening |first=Matt |authorlink=Matt Groening |editor1-first=Ray |editor1-last=Richmond |editor1-link=Ray Richmond |editor2-first=Antonia |editor2-last=Coffman |title=[[The Simpsons episode guides#The Simpsons: A Complete Guide to Our Favorite Family|The Simpsons: A Complete Guide to Our Favorite Family]] |others=Created by Matt Groening; edited by Ray Richmond and Antonia Coffman. |edition=1st |year=1997 |location=New York |publisher=Harper Perennial |lccn=98141857 |ol=433519M |oclc=37796735 |isbn=978-0-06-095252-5 |ref={{harvid|Richmond & Coffman|1997}}}} *{{cite book |last=Turner |first=Chris |authorlink=Chris Turner (author) |title=[[Planet Simpson|Planet Simpson: How a Cartoon Masterpiece Documented an Era and Defined a Generation]] |others=Foreword by [[Douglas Coupland]]. |edition=1st |year=2004 |location=Toronto |publisher=Random House Canada |oclc=55682258 |isbn=978-0-679-31318-2|ref=harv}} ==External links== {{Portal|The Simpsons}} {{sisterlinks|d=Q1020590|q=The Simpsons/Season 4#A Streetcar Named Marge|b=no|v=no|voy=no|s=no|m=no|mw=no|species=no|wikt=no|c=no|n=no}} *{{Official}} * {{snpp capsule|8F18}} * {{IMDb episode|0701048}} * {{tv.com episode|the-simpsons/a-streetcar-named-marge-1346}} {{A Streetcar Named Desire}} {{The Simpsons episodes|4}} {{Featured article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Streetcar Named Marge, A}} [[Category:The Simpsons (season 4) episodes]] [[Category:1992 American television episodes]] [[Category:Community theatre]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Alfred Hitchcock]]

revision.comment: /* United States */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: July of 2018 → July 2018
revision.text:
[[File:US album equivalent unit.png|thumb|250px|The standard of an album-equivalent unit in the United States, according to the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] and ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine.]] The '''album-equivalent unit''' is a measurement unit in [[music industry]] to define the consumption of music that equals the purchase of one [[album]] copy.<ref name="pitchfork"/><ref name="BillboardRule"/> This consumption includes [[streaming media|streaming]] and [[music download|song downloads]] in addition to traditional [[album sales]]. The album-equivalent unit was introduced in the mid-[[2010s]] as an answer to the drop of album sales in the 21st century. Album sales more than halved from 1999 to 2009, declining from a $14.6 to $6.3 billion industry.<ref>{{cite web|title=Why Album Sales Are Down|url=http://www.speeli.com/articles/view/Why-album-sales-are-down|website=Speeli|accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref> For instance, the only albums that [[Music_recording_certification|went platinum]] in the United States in 2014 were the ''[[Frozen (soundtrack)|Frozen]]'' soundtrack and [[Taylor Swift]]'s [[1989 (Taylor Swift album)|''1989'']], whereas several artists did in 2013.<ref name="noplat">{{Cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/hughmcintyre/2014/10/16/not-one-artists-album-has-gone-platinum-in-2014/ |title=Not One Artist's Album Has Gone Platinum In 2014 |last=McIntyre |first=Hugh |date=October 16, 2014 |work=[[Forbes]] |publisher=Forbes, Inc.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Sanders|first1=Sam|title=Taylor Swift, Platinum Party of One|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2014/11/05/361577726/taylor-swift-platinum-party-of-one|website=NPR}}</ref>
The usage of the album-equivalent units revolutionized the charts from the "best-selling albums" ranking into the "most popular albums" ranking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7393605/drakes-views-no-1-fifth-week-billboard-200|title=Drake's 'Views' Rules at No. 1 for Fifth Week on Billboard 200 Chart|first=Keith|last=Caulfield|work=Billboard|date=May 22, 2016|accessdate=July 2, 2016}}</ref> The [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]] (IFPI) have used album-equivalent unit to measure their [[Global Recording Artist of the Year]] since 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.org/global-artist-chart.php|title=Global Recording Artist of the Year|publisher=[[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]]|accessdate=November 11, 2017}}</ref>
==Uses on record charts== === United States === Beginning with the December 13, 2014 issue, the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] albums chart revised its ranking methodology with album-equivalent unit instead of pure album sales. With this overhaul, the ''Billboard'' 200 includes on-demand streaming and digital track sales (as measured by [[Nielsen SoundScan]]) by way of a new algorithm, utilizing data from all of the major on-demand audio subscription services including [[Spotify]], [[Apple Music]], [[Google Play]] and [[Xbox Music]]. Known as TEA (track equivalent album) and SEA (streaming equivalent album) when originally implemented, 10 song sales or 1,500 song streams from an album were treated as equivalent to one purchase of the album. ''Billboard'' continues to publish a pure album sales chart, called [[Top Album Sales]], that maintains the traditional ''Billboard'' 200 methodology, based exclusively on Nielsen SoundScan's sales data.<ref name="BillboardRule">{{cite news|first=Gary|last=Trust|title=Billboard 200 Makeover: Album Chart to Incorporate Streams & Track Sales|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6320099/billboard-200-makeover-streams-digital-tracks|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=2014-11-20|accessdate=2014-11-20}}</ref> Taylor Swift's ''1989'' was the first album to top the chart with this methodology, generating 339,000 album-equivalent units (281,000 units came from pure album sales).<ref name="pitchfork">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6334866/taylor-swift-1989-returns-no-1-billboard-200 |title=Taylor Swift's '1989' Returns to No. 1 on Revamped Billboard 200|work=billboard.com|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/thepitch/589-why-is-taylor-swift-still-1-interpreting-the-revamped-billboard-200-album-chart/ |title=Why Is Taylor Swift Still #1?|work=pitchfork.com|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> On the February 8, 2015 issue, ''[[Now That's What I Call Music! 53 (U.S. series)|Now That's What I Call Music! 53]]'' became the first album in history to miss the top position of the ''Billboard'' 200 despite being the best-selling album of the week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musictimes.com/articles/28306/20150212/now-53-outsells-taylor-swift-becomes-first-record-top-albums-kid-ink.htm|title=Now 53 Outsells Taylor Swift, Becomes First Record to Top Albums Chart but Not Billboard 200; Kid Ink Cracks Top 10|first=Ryan|last=Book|date=February 12, 2015|work=The Music Times|accessdate=July 2, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2018, Billboard and Nielsen revised the ratios used for streaming equivalent album units to account for the relative value of streams on paid music services like Apple Music or Amazon Music Unlimited versus ad-supported music and video platforms such as Spotify's free tier and YouTube. Under the updated album equivalent ratios, 1,250 premium audio streams, 3,750 ad-supported streams, or 3,750 video streams are equal to one album unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/09/arts/music/drake-scorpion-streams-billboard-chart.html|title=The Music Industry’s Math Changes, but the Outcome Doesn’t: Drake Is No. 1|first=Ben|last=Sisario|date=July 9, 2018|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 25, 2018}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === In the United Kingdom, the [[Official Charts Company]] has included streaming into the [[UK Albums Chart]] since March 2015.<ref name="Sam">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6487512/sam-smiths-in-the-lonely-hour-tops-historic-uk-albums-chart |title=Sam Smith's 'In the Lonely Hour' Tops Historic U.K. Albums Chart|work=billboard.com|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> The change was decided after the massive growth of streaming; the number of tracks streamed in the UK in a year doubled from 7.5 billion in 2013 to just under 15 billion in 2014. Under the new methodology, Official Charts Company takes the 12 most-streamed tracks from an album, with the top two songs being given lesser weight so that the figure will reflect the popularity of the album as a whole rather than of one or two successful [[single (music)|singles]]. The adjusted total is divided by 1000 and added to the album sales figure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/uk-s-official-albums-chart-to-include-streaming-data-for-first-time__8012/ |title=Official Albums Chart to include streaming data for first time|work=officialcharts.com|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> [[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]]'s ''[[In the Lonely Hour]]'' was the first album to top the chart with this rule. Out of its 41,000 album-equivalent units, 2,900 units came from streaming and the rest were pure sales.<ref name="Sam"/> By the end of 2017, The BPI reported that streaming now accounts for over half of music consumption in the UK (50.4%).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/drakes-official-top-40-most-streamed-songs__21625/|title=Drake's Official Top 40 most streamed songs|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en}}</ref>
=== Germany === In Germany, streaming began to be included on the albums chart since February 2016. Nevertheless, [[German Albums Chart]] is used to ranking the albums based on weekly [[revenue]], instead of units. Hence, only paid streaming is counted and should be played at least 30 seconds. At least 6 tracks of one album have to be streamed to make streams count for the album, with 12 tracks being the maximum counted. Similar to the UK chart rule, the actual streams of the top-two songs are not counted, but instead the average of the following tracks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musikmarkt.de/Aktuell/News/Deutsche-Album-Charts-integrieren-Premium-Streaming|archive-url=https://archive.is/20160201142531/http://www.musikmarkt.de/Aktuell/News/Deutsche-Album-Charts-integrieren-Premium-Streaming|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 1, 2016|publisher=Musikmarkt.de|language=German|title=Deutsche Album-Charts integrieren Premium-Streaming|date=February 1, 2016|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Deutsche-Album-Charts-jetzt-auch-mit-Streaming-Zahlen-3089360.html|title=Deutsche Album-Charts jetzt auch mit Streaming-Zahlen|first=Volker|last=Briegleb|date=February 1, 2016|publisher=[[Heinz Heise]]|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref>
==Criticism== In [[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes.com]], Hugh McIntyre noted that the usage of album equivalent units has made artists release albums with excessive track lists.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/hughmcintyre/2017/08/17/how-longer-albums-and-streaming-giants-are-manipulating-the-charts/2/#69d2965051b3|title=How Longer Albums And Streaming Giants Are Manipulating The Charts|publisher=Forbes|date=2017-08-17|accessdate=2018-08-05}}</ref> Brian Josephs from ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' said: "If you’re a thirsty pop artist of note, you can theoretically game the system by packing as many as 20 tracks into an album, in the process rolling up more album-equivalent units—and thus album "sales"—as listeners check the album out." He also criticized [[Chris Brown]]'s album ''[[Heartbreak on a Full Moon]]'' which contains over 40 songs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2017/05/chris-brown-new-album-40-song-tracklist-heartbreak-on-a-full-moon/|title=Why Does Chris Brown’s New Album Have 40 Songs?|date=2017-05-02|publisher=Spin|accessdate=2018-08-05}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Album sales]]

revision.text:
{{for|the book by Casey Sherman and Dave Wedge|Boston Strong (book)}} [[File:Massachusetts State House Red Sox Banner.JPG|thumb|The [[Massachusetts State House]] displays a Boston Strong banner during the [[2013 World Series]].]] "'''Boston Strong'''" is a slogan that was created as part of the reaction to the [[Boston Marathon bombing]] in April 2013. It is a variation on the term [[Livestrong]], which was created in 2004. It has been placed on various kinds of merchandise after the phrase became popular, as well as gained criticism from various entities.<ref name=Zimmer>{{cite news|last=Zimmer|first=Ben|title="Boston Strong," the phrase that rallied a city|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/ideas/2013/05/11/boston-strong-phrase-that-rallied-city/uNPFaI8Mv4QxsWqpjXBOQO/story.html|accessdate=3 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=12 May 2013}}</ref> The use of the term in Boston has led to similar phrases entering public discourse, such as America Strong.
==History== In the hours after the [[Boston Marathon bombing]] on April 15, 2013, the slogan "Boston Strong" appeared as a highly popular hashtag on [[Twitter]] and rapidly spread around the world. It was a [[T-shirt]] campaign created by Christopher Dobens and Nicholas Reynolds, students at [[Emerson College]]. An expression of [[Boston]]'s unity after the bombings, the slogan showed up on T-shirts and other products, and was emblazoned on the "Green Monster" wall at Boston's [[Fenway Park]].<ref name=NBCNewsApril21>{{cite web|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/21/17850375-boston-strong-emerges-as-rallying-cry-from-stadiums-to-tweets |title='Boston Strong' emerges as rallying cry, from stadiums to tweets |publisher=NBC News |date=April 21, 2013 |first=Lou |last=Dubois}}</ref><ref name=Dicker/> The [[Boston Bruins]] displayed the slogan on their helmets at their game two days after the bombings,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prohockeytalk.nbcsports.com/2013/04/17/video-bruins-honor-victims-first-responders-of-boston-marathon-tragedy/ |title=Bruins honor victims, first responders of Boston Marathon tragedy |first=Mike |last=Halford |date=April 17, 2013 |publisher=NBC News}}</ref> and at the first [[baseball]] game in Fenway Park after the bombings, the stadium announcer told the crowd: "We are one. We are strong. We are Boston. We are Boston strong."<ref name=NBCNewsApril21/>
On April 17, two days after the bombings, a T-shirt vendor and another private individual submitted separate [[trademark]] registration applications to the [[U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]], seeking to obtain ownership of the "Boston Strong" slogan for use on commercial products.<ref name=Dicker/> One of the applicants said he wanted the trademark in order to prevent people from outside the Boston area from benefiting from it. A [[trademark attorney]] was quoted in ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' as predicting that the government office would deny the registration on the grounds that the slogan was already in the public domain and could not be linked to any specific entity.<ref name=Dicker>{{cite news|last=Dicker|first=Rick|title=Boston Strong' Trademark Race Begins; Two File Just Days After Boston Marathon Bombing|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/22/boston-strong-trademark_n_3131857.html|accessdate=3 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=22 April 2013}}</ref>
On July 17, 2013, Boston Strong Bostonstrong.com LLC submitted [[trademark]] application to the [[U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]], the first for "Charitable Fundraising to Support Disaster Relief", and failed to receive registration in April 2014. Boston Strong bostonstrong.com was created 11/29/2012, well before anyone was interested in the mark, and was used as a man-made and natural disaster safety awareness advertising and disaster news campaign created by a North East and New England documentary news journalist reporting on the Appalachian Thrust and Lower Atlantic Region. VTstrong.com "Don't Drive into Water" campaign began in 2011 when Hurricane Irene's five-inch rain caused historic downhill water rapids and valley flooding that devastated Vermont. The goods manufactured by the micro–small business inventor sold via bostonstrong.com to create Boston Strong Disaster Relief, Inc., bostonstrong.org, a MA non-profit, on March 17, 2015. The non-profit is an IRS 501c3 approved charity and is administrating the MassDOT MA State Boston Strong license plate. Boston Strong Disaster Relief, Inc. is a registered service mark trademark in the State of MA as of 4/13/2015. The organization is 100% volunteer and benefits Boston bombing survivors' long term medical needs not covered by insurance.
The One Fund Boston, a trademark that received registration, collected and distributed over $80 million, is closed in 2015.
In late May, a concert, Boston Strong: An Evening of Support and Celebration, was held at [[TD Garden]] with performances by [[Aerosmith]], [[James Taylor]], [[Bell Biv Devoe]], [[New Kids on the Block]] [[J. Geils Band]], [[Boston (band)|Boston]], [[Godsmack]], [[Extreme (band)|Extreme]], [[Jason Aldean]], [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Carole King]], [[Dane Cook]] and [[Steven Wright]].<ref name=WCVB>{{cite news|title=Boston Marathon concert to feature music icons Aerosmith, James Taylor, NKOTB concert benefits One Fund|url=http://www.wcvb.com/entertainment/boston-marathon-concert-to-feature-music-icons/20314190#ixzz2vbBOd3YT|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=[[WCVB]]|date=30 May 2013}}</ref>
The Boston Strong entertainment industry concert videos online and money they generate is not associated with the bostonstrong.org charity.
The term has also made its way into many publications since the bombings, as well.<ref name=Rosen>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Judith|title=Boston Strong—In Books|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/61330-boston-strong-in-books.html|publisher=[[Publishers Weekly]]|accessdate=10 March 2014|date=6 March 2014}}</ref>
==Etymology== The roots of Boston Strong can be traced back to the Livestrong bracelets marketed by the [[Livestrong Foundation]] in 2003. The phrase can also be traced back to the [[United States Army]]'s Army Strong motto, as well as Jersey Strong (Work Out World gym), which became popular in [[New Jersey]] following the destruction of [[Hurricane Sandy]].<ref name=Zimmer /> Man-Made and Natural disaster non-entertainment news affiliates Boston Strong bostonstrong.com was created 11/29/2012, 15 months after affiliate VTstrong.com was created in 2011 following Hurricane Irene mountain floods. NewJerseyStrong.com was created 10/2012 as Hurricane Sandy struck the lower Atlantic.
==Criticism== [[Wesley Lowery]], then a reporter at ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', tweeted in October 2013 that he thought the phrase had become overly commercialized, a view which drew criticism though Lowery's tweet specified he was "still inspired by the resilience of so many of those wounded in the marathon bombings."<ref name=Klonoski>{{cite news|last=Klonoski|first=Brian|title=Boston Globe Reporter Wesley Lowery Is 'So Tired of Boston Strong'|url=http://www.ryot.org/boston-globe-reporter-wesley-lowery-tired-boston-strong/443245|accessdate=3 March 2014|newspaper=RYOT|date=26 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027081456/http://www.ryot.org/boston-globe-reporter-wesley-lowery-tired-boston-strong/443245#|archive-date=2013-10-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://archive.boston.com/blogs/news/local/chartgirl/2013/10/_view_the_story_thou.html|title=Thou shall not tweet anything negative about "Boston Strong"|last=Sargent|first=Hillary|date=October 25, 2013|work=Boston.com|access-date=September 13, 2016|via=}}</ref> A few weeks later, [[Bill Maher]] criticized the term, referring to a moment when he said: "You know again it was a bad day. Three people died that's terrible, more were maimed that's horrible, but unfortunately that happens every day in car accidents and everything else. I mean your city was not leveled by [[Godzilla]]." The remarks came in response to the [[2013 World Series]] celebration, when [[Boston Red Sox]] players [[Jarrod Saltalamacchia]] and [[Jonny Gomes]] walked to the finish line of the [[Boston Marathon]] and placed the World Series Trophy on the line, while the crowd sang "[[God Bless America]]". Former Mayor [[Thomas Menino]] later called Maher's comments "irresponsible."<ref name=WBZ>{{cite news|title=Menino Says Bill Maher's Boston Bombing Comments Were "Irresponsible"|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2013/11/14/menino-calls-bill-mahers-boston-bombing-comments-irresponsible/|accessdate=3 March 2014|newspaper=[[WBZ-TV|WBZ]]|date=14 November 2013}}</ref>
In February 2014, a charitable organization in [[El Paso, Texas]] considered taking possible legal action against the Red Sox due to their using a variation of the slogan, "B Strong", which it started using seven years earlier.<ref name=WBZ3>{{cite news|title=Report: Red Sox May Be Sued By Charitable Foundation Over Use Of 'B Strong' Logo|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2014/02/28/report-red-sox-may-be-sued-by-charitable-foundation-over-use-of-b-strong-logo/|accessdate=3 March 2014|newspaper=WBZ|date=28 February 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Commons category-inline|Boston Strong}}

revision.text:
'''Castle Bryant Johnsen''' is a [[television]] computer artistry group, working specifically in the field of [[title sequence]]s. The group, consisting of James Castle, Bruce Bryant and Carol Johnsen, has created opening titles for television series, including ''[[As the World Turns]]'' (1993-1999), ''[[ALF (TV series)|ALF]]'', ''[[Knots Landing]]'' (1989-1993), ''[[Growing Pains]]'', ''[[Roseanne (TV series)|Roseanne]]'' (1995-1997), ''[[Moonlighting (TV series)|Moonlighting]]'', ''[[The X-Files]]'', ''[[Cheers]]'', ''[[JAG (TV series)|JAG]]'' and ''[[Frasier]]''.
The Castle Bryant Johnsen group has won multiple [[Emmy Award]]s for their title sequences.
==External links== *[http://www.salon.com/06/reviews/titles.html Salon magazine interview with Carol Johnsen]

revision.text:
{{short description|British philosopher}} {{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Western philosophy]] |era = [[Contemporary philosophy|21st-century philosophy]] |color = |image = |name = '''Elisabeth Schellekens''' |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |school_tradition = | institutions = [[Uppsala University]] |main_interests = [[aesthetics]], [[ethics]] | thesis_title = A Reasonable Objectivism for Aesthetic Judgments: Towards An Aesthetic Psychology | thesis_url = https://sas-space.sas.ac.uk/1056/1/Elisabeth%20Schellekens%20-%20PhD%20Thesis.pdf | thesis_year = 2003 | doctoral_advisor = [[Peter Goldie]] | doctoral_students = |notable_ideas = | spouse = Guy Dammann | education = [[King's College London]] (PhD)
[[University of Edinburgh]] (MA) | alma_mater = |influences = [[David Hume]], [[Immanuel Kant]] |influenced = |awards = |website = https://katalog.uu.se/profile/?id=N13-2457 }} '''Anna Elisabeth Schellekens Dammann''' is a British philosopher and Chair Professor of Aesthetics at [[Uppsala University]] (since 2014). She is known for her works on [[aesthetics]] and [[ethics]].{{cite journal |last1=Harold |first1=James |title=Review of Aesthetics and Morality |journal=Notre Dame Philosophical Reviews |date=13 July 2008 |url=https://ndpr.nd.edu/news/aesthetics-and-morality/ |accessdate=23 November 2018 |issn=1538-1617}}{{cite journal |last1=Yanal |first1=Robert J. |title=Review of Philosophy and Conceptual Art |journal=Notre Dame Philosophical Reviews |date=30 May 2008 |url=https://ndpr.nd.edu/news/philosophy-and-conceptual-art/ |accessdate=23 November 2018 |issn=1538-1617}}{{cite journal |last1=Puolakka |first1=Kalle |title=Elisabeth Schellekens, Aesthetics and Morality |journal=[[The Nordic Journal of Aesthetics]] |date=6 February 2012 |volume=23 |issue=42 |doi=10.7146/nja.v23i42.5878 |url=https://tidsskrift.dk/nja/article/view/5878 |accessdate=23 November 2018 |issn=2000-1452}} Schellekens is co-editor of the ''[[British Journal of Aesthetics]]''. Previously, she was Senior Lecturer at [[Durham University]] (2006-2014). ==Career== She received her MA (Hons.) and MSc (Res) from the [[University of Edinburgh]] and completed her PhD at [[King's College London]] in 2003. She held a post-doctoral research fellowship at King's from 2003 to 2006. Schellekens was then appointed at Durham as Lecturer. She is a member of the ''[[Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism]]'''s editorial board. ==Personal life== She is married to the musicologist and critic Guy Dammann. They have two children. ==Published works== *''[[Aesthetics and Morality]]'' (Continuum Books, 2007) *''[[Who's Afraid of Conceptual Art]]'', with [[Peter Goldie]] (Routledge, 2009) ===Edited collections=== *''[[Philosophy and Conceptual Art]]'', with Peter Goldie (Oxford University Press, 2007) *''[[The Aesthetic Mind]]'', with Peter Goldie (Oxford University Press, 2011) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://katalog.uu.se/profile/?id=N13-2457 Elisabeth Schellekens at Uppsala University] {{Authority Control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schellekens, Elisabeth}} [[Category:Academics of Durham University]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Philosophers of art]] [[Category:Moral philosophers]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Alumni of King's College London]] [[Category:Uppsala University faculty]] [[Category:British women academics]] [[Category:British women philosophers]] {{UK-academic-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{About|the children's book|the TV series based on the book|Fancy Nancy (TV series)|the Skip & Flip single|Skip & Flip}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox book | name = Fancy Nancy | title_orig = | translator = | image = FancyNancy.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | author = Jane O'Connor | illustrator = Robin Preiss Glasser | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = Picture book | publisher = [[HarperCollins]] | pub_date = December 2005 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print (hardcover) | pages = 32 pp | isbn = 0-06-054209-8 | dewey= [E] 22 | congress= PZ7.O222 Fa 2006 | oclc= 57243365 | preceded_by = | followed_by = [[Fancy Nancy and the Posh Puppy]] }}
'''''Fancy Nancy''''' is a 2005 [[Children's literature|children's picture book]] written by Jane O'Connor and illustrated by [[Robin Preiss Glasser]]. The book spent nearly 100 weeks on the [[New York Times Best Seller list]],<ref name="OCReview">{{Cite news| last = Sforza| first = Teri| author2 = | title ='Fancy Nancy' strikes little girls' fancy| work = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[The Orange County Register]]| date = February 11, 2008| url = http://www.ocregister.com/articles/fancy-nancy-childrens-1977903-books-robin| accessdate = 2009-03-16}}</ref> launching a series that now numbers upwards of 80 books, selling 30 million volumes. ''Fancy Nancy'' has been on [[Publishers Weekly]]'s bestseller list for picture books, was a Children's Book-of-the-Month Club selection and a Junior Library Guild Selection. It also won a "Borders 2006 Original Voices" award<ref name="Playthings">{{Cite news |url=http://www.playthings.com/article/CA6414044.html |title=United to unveil Fancy Nancy toys |last=staff |date=February 7, 2007 |publisher=Playthings |accessdate=2009-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505192307/http://www.playthings.com/article/CA6414044.html |archivedate=May 5, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref> and has been translated into 20 languages, including Hungarian and Hebrew. In April 2012, Nancy was featured in her first chapter book, ''Nancy Clancy: Super Sleuth''. Books in the ''Fancy Nancy'' series have now spent 330 weeks on the [[New York Times Best Seller list]], and in the fall of 2012, ''[[Fancy Nancy the Musical]]'' was produced by Vital Theatre Company in New York City.
==Plot introduction== Fancy Nancy is a young girl with a larger than life personality, who adores all things fancy. She always dresses extravagantly, wearing [[Feather boa|boas]], [[Ballet tutu|tutus]], [[ruby slippers]], fairy wings, and fuzzy slippers. Nancy loves using big fancy words such as "iridescent", "ecstatic", and "extraordinary" and anything in French.<ref name="OCReview"/><ref name="HC-Berkowitz">{{Cite news|title=BOOKS – Don't forget your tiara: It's a "Fancy" soiree – Celebration toasts author and illustrator |last=Berkowitz|first=Lana|date=March 27, 2007|publisher=Houston Chronicle}}</ref> She has redecorated her bedroom with everyday items, such as feather boas, Christmas lights, paper flowers, and hats. Her favorite doll is named Marabelle Lavinia Chandelier.<ref name="NYTReview">{{Cite news| last = Jenkins| first = Emily| author2 = | title ='Fancy Nancy,' by Jane O'Connor. Illustrated by Robin Preiss Glasser. | pages = | language = | work = [[The New York Times]]| date = March 12, 2006| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/12/books/review/12jenk.html | accessdate = 2009-03-16}}</ref> {{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#FFFFF0 |salign=center |width=30em |Nancy captures hearts by nearly getting caught up in the glitter, but, in the end, always discovering what's truly important.|Teri Sforza<ref name="OCReview"/>}} In Nancy's opinion, her family is ordinary and dresses rather plainly, so Nancy decides to hold a class in the art of fanciness for her family. They oblige, and Nancy helps to dress them in bows, ornaments, top hats, and gaudy scarves. "Ooo-la-la!" Nancy cries in delight. "My family is posh! That's a fancy word for fancy."<ref name="NYTReview"/>
==Jane O'Connor== Jane O'Connor is vice-president and editor-at-large for Penguin Books for Young Readers!<ref name="Sparkles">{{Cite news| last = Lodge | first = Sally| title = From Sparkles to Sales, Nancy Is Fancy Indeed | publisher = [[Publishers Weekly]]| date = January 31, 2007| url = http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/childrens/childrens-book-news/article/16091-from-sparkles-to-sales-nancy-is-fancy-indeed.html |accessdate = January 16, 2015}}</ref> She has written more than thirty children's books. Her first adult novel, ''Dangerous Admissions: Secrets of a Closet Sleuth'' came out in July 2007.<ref name="Sparkles"/>
O'Connor came up with Fancy Nancy on a summer evening. As she describes it, "It was after dinner one evening that the title just came to me," she recalls. "I sat down and wrote the first and last paragraphs. The rest of the story took me awhile, but the beginning and the end just flew into my head."<ref name="Playthings"/><ref name="Sparkles"/> O'Connor is quick to point out that much of the book's success is Glasser's artwork. She wrote the book in 2002, but it did not come out until 2005, because her editor, Margaret Anastas, insisted on Glasser as the illustrator who was busy with other projects.<ref name="HC-Berkowitz"/><ref name="Sparkles"/>
==Robin Preiss Glasser== {{main article|Robin Preiss Glasser}}
In 2013 Glasser was named 2013 Illustrator of the Year by the Children's Book Council for ''Fancy Nancy and the Mermaid Ballet'' after more than 1 million young people cast their votes<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbcbooks.org/sub-news.php?id=1005 |title=Archived copy |access-date=June 18, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130808192138/http://www.cbcbooks.org/sub-news.php?id=1005#.UcCSU1oo6bg |archive-date=August 8, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> in the 6th annual Children's Choice Book Awards.
==Marketing== ''Fancy Nancy'' has spawned a line of toys and games focusing on dress-up and role play targeted towards preschoolers and children aged 5 to 7. In addition, the Fancy Nancy brand includes licenses for clothing, paper party goods, crafts, and more. Numerous bookstores and libraries around the United States have hosted events including readings by both Jane O'Connor and Robin Preiss Glasser, costume contests, “Fancy Nancy” days and tea parties.<ref name="Playthings"/>
A Fancy Nancy game called ''Fancy Nancy: Tea Party Time!'' for the [[Nintendo DS]] systems was released on September 14, 2010.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
There are three Fancy Nancy apps for the iPad and iPhone: Fancy Nancy Dress Up,<ref>{{cite web|title=Fancy Nancy Dress Up|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/fancy-nancy-dress-up/id481109944?mt=8|publisher=iTunes}}</ref> Fancy Nancy Explorer Extraordinaire,<ref>{{cite web|title=Fancy Nancy Explorer Extraordinaire|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/fancy-nancy-explorer-extraordinaire/id494587885?mt=8|publisher=iTunes}}</ref> and Fancy Nancy Ballet School.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fancy Nancy Ballet School|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/fancy-nancy-ballet-school/id553383738?mt=8|publisher=iTunes}}</ref>
== Adaptations == In 2012, [[20th Century Fox]] and [[Shawn Levy|21 Laps Entertainment]] announced a live-action version of Fancy Nancy book series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Fox-Acquires-Rights-Fancy-Nancy-Book-Series-29273.html|title=Fox Acquires Rights To Fancy Nancy Book Series|date=February 6, 2012|publisher=|accessdate=May 24, 2018}}</ref> [[Tina Fey]] and [[Shawn Levy]] are the production team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/02/08/fancy-nancy-tina-fey/|title=Tina Fey to produce live-action 'Fancy Nancy' movie|publisher=|accessdate=May 24, 2018}}</ref>
In March 2015, [[Disney Junior]] announced that an [[Fancy Nancy (TV series)|animated television movie and TV series]] of ''Fancy Nancy'' were both in the works. The series premiered on July 13, 2018.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pedersen |first1=Erik |title=‘Fancy Nancy’ Renewed By Disney Junior Ahead Of Series Premiere |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/fancy-nancy-renewed-season-2-disney-junior-alyson-hannigan-rob-riggle-1202405245/ |website=Deadline |accessdate=8 June 2018 |date=7 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Littleton|first1=Cynthia|title='Fancy Nancy' Set to Become Disney Junior Movie, TV Series|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/fancy-nancy-disney-book-series-animated-movie-tv-1201461137/|website=Variety.com|accessdate=January 6, 2016}}</ref>
=== Musicals === In 2012, ''[[Fancy Nancy the Musical]]'' was produced Off-Broadway by Vital Theatre Company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vitaltheatre.org|title=Vital Theatre Company - Welcome|website=vitaltheatre.org|accessdate=May 24, 2018}}</ref> The musical is mainly based on ''Fancy Nancy and the Mermaid Ballet'', with book and lyrics by [[Susan DiLallo]] and music and lyrics by [[Danny Abosch]]. The Original Off-Broadway Cast Recording of ''Fancy Nancy the Musical'' was released on [[Ghostlight Records]] in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sh-k-boom.com/fancynancy.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=March 8, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130313072210/http://www.sh-k-boom.com/fancynancy.html |archive-date=March 13, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In 2014 ''[[Fancy Nancy: Splendiferous Christmas]]'' was produced Off-Broadway by [[Vital Theatre Company, Inc.]]. The musical, based on the book of the same title, has a book by Cara Lustik, music by Randy Klein and lyrics by Matthew Hardy.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/21/arts/spare-times-for-children-for-nov-21-27.html|title=Spare Times for Children for Nov. 21-27|date=November 20, 2014|publisher=|accessdate=May 24, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> The Original Off-Broadway cast album was released in 2015 and is available from Jazzhead Records. The production was performed in New York City and on tour during 2015 and 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fancynancychristmaslive.com|title=Fancy Nancy: Splendiferous Christmas|publisher=|accessdate=May 24, 2018}}</ref>
==Series== Initially, O'Connor and Glasser signed a contract for two books with HarperCollins, but after the success of the first book, they later signed to do 13 additional Fancy Nancy titles across a variety of formats.<ref name="Sparkles"/> Since then, they've collaborated on 80 titles.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.fancynancyworld.com Official Site] * [http://www.robinpreissglasser.com Official Site of Illustrator, Robin Preiss Glasser]
